Award.AwardTitle: Stable Isotopic Constraints on Nitrogen Transformations in Low and High Temperature Hydrothermal Fluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1
This project will address deficiencies in our understanding of Nitrogen transformations under hydrothermal conditions with implications for the fate of bioavailable Nitrogen in the modern subsurface biosphere and of reduced Nitrogen on pre-biotic Earth. Through the PIs the project will advance the utility of Nitrogen isotopic composition in active submarine hydrothermal systems. Three hypotheses will be tested concerning: the reaction temperature and redox state of hydrothermal reaction zones; NH4+ in high temperature vent fluids; and NH4+ and NO3- in low-temperature vent fluids. To address these hypotheses, the PI's plan combined experimental and observational approaches. Well-constrained laboratory experiments will be conducted to determine operative reaction pathways and associated N isotopic fraction during redox dependent reactions involving dissolved N species under hydrothermal conditions. In addition, measurements will be made in high and low temperature hydrothermal vent fluids from existing samples spanning a range of hydrothermal environments to constrain abiotic and microbially mediated processes that influence the abundance of aqueous N species in submarine hot springs. The broader impacts consist of educational opportunities for students at various levels.

Part 2
This project aims to address existing deficiencies in our understanding of nitrogen transformations under hydrothermal conditions with implications for the fate of bioavailable nitrogen in the modern subsurface biosphere and of reduced nitrogen on pre-biotic Earth. Through the examination of the controls on reaction pathways, rates, and associated stable isotope systematics, this project will advance the utility of nitrogen isotopic composition in active submarine hydrothermal systems, and help to constrain geologic records of nitrogen isotopic composition. This research is guided by the hypotheses that 1) reaction temperature and redox state of hydrothermal reaction zones regulate the geochemical conversion of nitrate (NO3-) and possibly dinitrogen (N2) to ammonium, that 2) the stable nitrogen isotopic composition of NH4+ in high temperature vent fluids will record the relative roles of these reaction processes and that 3) variations in the abundance and isotopic composition of NH4+ and NO3- in low-temperature vent fluids in concert with their corresponding high temperature endmember source fluids can be used to constrain the nature and extent of subsurface biological processes. To address these hypotheses, the PI?s plan combined experimental and observational approaches. Well-constrained laboratory experiments will be conducted to determine operative reaction pathways and associated N isotopic fraction during redox dependent reactions involving dissolved N species under hydrothermal conditions. In addition, the abundance and N (and O) isotopic composition o NH4+ (and NO3-) will be measured from high and low temperature hydrothermal vent fluids from a rich archive of samples spanning a range of hydrothermal environments to constrain abiotic and microbially mediated processes that influence the abundance of aqueous N species in submarine hot springs. The broader impacts consist of educational opportunities for students at various levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to improve our understanding of major processes contributing to nitrogen speciation (and thus, availability) during hydrothermal circulation and within hydrothermal ecosystems. We specifically focused on the use of nitrogen stable isotopes as integrators of sources and cycling processes for elucidating transformation mechanisms across a range of reaction conditions. A portion of this project included a series of high temperature, high pressure experiments of nitrate reduction under mineral-buffered redox conditions. Results generally indicated a range in the kinetic isotopic effects imparted on nitrate N and O (15e and 18e), yet revealed a strong coupling of these N and O isotope effects, with 18e:15e values clustering near 0.6.  Intriguingly, this dual isotope trend is distinct from that largely imparted by biological denitrification (18e:15e ~1), yet remains indistinguishable from biological nitrate reduction by periplasmic nitrate reductase (NAP), an enzyme widely utilized by chemoautotrophic nitrate reducers, including the cosmopolitan populations of sulfur oxidizing bacteria ubiquitously found throughout many hydrothermal vent ecosystems. These experiments also shed light on the reaction conditions that influence the product of high temperature nitrate reduction. Whereas, previous studies have largely assumed a quantitative conversion of nitrate to ammonium at high temperature, our results indicated production of both NH4+ and N2 when reaction conditions were buffered at low pH (4.5). Overall, these results shed light on potential mechanisms to explain the regularly lower levels of ammonium found in high temperature vent fluids with respect to levels of nitrate in bottom seawater.

Complementary to this experimental work, we also looked to an existing archive of fluid samples collected from hydrothermal vent systems worldwide to make new N isotope analyses of NH4+ to help shed light on N sources and processes that concentrations alone might not reveal. To this end, we measured N isotopic composition in ammonium from approximately 60 high temperature fluid samples spanning a range of vent type including ultra-slow and to moderate spreading mid-ocean ridges, sedimented and unsedimented systems, back arc basins and even warm off-axis crustal fluids. This set of analyses nearly doubled the existing amount of data on submarine N isotopes. We compiled these new data and together with all data published to date to explore patterns among regions and venting types. Concentrations at millimolar levels were commonly found in sediment-covered vent fields, while much lower (uM) levels were typical of unsedimented systems. While the source of ammonium in the sedimented systems almost entirely derives from the sedimentary origin, as indicated by the tight clustering of fluid ammonium isotopic composition with that of the source sediment organic matter, the production of ammonium in unsedimented systems was more variable and clearly more easily influenced by a number of other possible processes. Among these, and perhaps most difficult to assess, is the extent to which fluids are modified during recharge by biological processes in the warm crust. Isotopic modification of these source fluids by microbial communities catalyzing nitrate respiration, likely increases the N isotope values of source nitrate entering any higher temperature reaction zones. In this way, fluid residence times and circulation pathways likely play an important role in the ultimate composition of NH4+ emanating from  high temperature vents.

Finally, we also examined ammonium isotope compositions found in low temperature environments – using both field samples as well as new analyses of previously conducted incubation experiments. A previous study showed that variations in temperature and dissolved hydrogen or hydrogen sulfide content shifted the biological processes responsible for consuming nitrate – ultimately producing either ammonium or N2 gas. Our isotopic measurements of the product ammonium exhibited an exceptionally high level of variability among replicate experiments, despite similar patterns in concentration. This high level of isotopic variability was also noted in the field samples of low-temperature fluids, and is consistent with the strong influence that reaction pathway branching (among multiple N products) can play on product isotopic composition. In the end, constraining the dynamics of these processes proved very difficult given our limited understanding of how microbial populations impact isotopic fractionation under these conditions and how the composition and physiology of these communities may rapidly shift over time (and space). Future work would benefit from a close coupling of microbial transcriptomics approaches with geochemical and stable isotopic composition to reign in some of this complexity.
